snippet.description:
Tourist arrivals to Singapore fell by 85% in 2020 with 2.7 million visitors, compared to the record-high of 19.1 million visitors in 2019. Tourism receipts were also down almost 80%. See how Singapore's tourism sector is moving to new revenue streams. 


#Singapore #Tourism #Staycation #Travel

snippet.description:
Globally, video games revenue is projected to exceed US$180 billion in 2021. More than half of that is expected to come from game downloads. In Singapore, game developer Desmond Wong co-founded The Gentlebros in 2015 with best friends, Leon and Syaz. Their games have had more than 1.3 million downloads worldwide. After Cat Quest‚Äôs phenomenal success, Desmond and his team are exploring how AI can help in the next iteration of their game.

#CNAInsider #GameNation #Gentlebros #CatQuest #Gaming

Tammy is the founder of the world‚Äôs first eSports league for female gamers. The FSL League is run from Singapore, attracting teams and players from Malaysia, Thailand, Taiwan, Indonesia, Vietnam, India, ANZ and even Mongolia.

Tammy feels that eSports levels the playing field, as long as one has the mental fortitude and focus eSports can be for everyone.

Thomas was 23 when he represented Singapore in the 2019 Sea Games. It was the first multi-sport competition to have eSports as a medalled event. But winning silver in Star Craft II is not enough. Thomas has embarked on a rigorous training regime in his bid to win gold in the 2021 Southeast Asian Games.

snippet.description:
Newsnight has learned countries in the WHO have agreed they need to consider sidestepping patents to help with global vaccine supplies. Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

As the World Health Organisation officials have warned the world is on the brink of a "catastrophic moral failure" because of unequal Covid vaccine policies, pressure is growing on pharmaceutical companies to be forced to waive the patent protections on their vaccines.
¬†
India and South Africa are part of a group of countries who have been arguing they need to be able to make their own vaccines without getting a license first.
¬†
Newsnight has seen a document revealing that for the first time countries in the World Health Organisation have agreed they need to consider moving on patents to help with global vaccine supplies.
¬†
Should global political leaders abandon patent protections?
¬†
Newsnight‚Äôs Health Correspondent Deb Cohen reports. Emma Barnett is joined by former President of Ireland and UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, now chair of The Elders, Mary Robinson and Director-General of the International Federation of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers & Associations, Thomas Cueni.

#Newsnight #BBCNews

Newsnight is the BBC's flagship news and current affairs TV programme - with analysis, debate, exclusives, and robust interviews. 

Website: https://www.bbc.co.uk/newsnight
Twitter: https://twitter.com/BBCNewsnight
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/bbcnewsnight

snippet.description:
Scientists have been using a new form of gene therapy to treat a rare inherited eye condition which eventually causes severe tunnel vision. 

Scientists have been using the new treatment on patients to try to halt further loss of sight.  And  they've been astonished to find that it has actually improved their vision. 

Sophie Raworth presents BBC News at Ten reporting by medical editor Fergus Walsh.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
President Biden has marked his first 100 days in office by launching radical and ambitious proposals for America, a ‚Äúonce in a generation‚Äù investment plan as he called it. 

If enacted, it could be transformational.  It comes at a huge cost - four trillion dollars. Much of it would be paid for by tax rises for corporations and for the most wealthy. 

The American Families Plan aims to cut child poverty and put a cap on child care costs.  

It's hoped it will create millions of jobs through a massive programme of investment in infrastructure, broadband and green energy.

However President Biden faces a battle in Congress, especially over raising higher taxes.  

Sophie Raworth presents BBC News at Ten reporting by north America editor Jon Sopel.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
A Sikh temple, or Gurdwara, in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh is providing drive-through oxygen supplies to Covid patients.

More than 1,000 people have used the service so far, as the country's hospitals become overwhelmed with the number of rising cases of the disease.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

snippet.description:
Fans have celebrated outside a California courthouse after news was announced that Britney Spears would speak in court about her conservatorship. 

The singer's father, Jamie Spears, was granted control over her personal and business affairs in a court-ordered conservatorship in 2008, but she has now indicated she no longer wants him to have such control.

It is unclear if Spears will appear in person but the judge has set a hearing date for 23 June.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BritneySpears #BBCNews

Sayyed Munir Kamruddin and his colleagues have been working 24-hour shifts to bury those killed by the coronavirus. The 52-year-old gravedigger has been overwhelmed as India‚Äôs Covid-19 infections soar. Official data shows that more than 300,000 people across the country have tested positive in the past week; 3,645 patients died on April 29, setting a new record for India‚Äôs highest single-day death toll so far.

The coronavirus is especially harsh on elderly people, but a 105-year-old 
Indian man and his 95-year-old wife have beaten Covid-19, according to local reports. 
Living in India's worst-hit state of Maharashtra, centenarian Dhenu Umaji Chavan and his wife Motabai contracted the virus in March 2021. After 10 days of treatment at a government hospital in Latur district they were discharged on April 4, having tested negative for the virus. The family of the elderly couple hope their recovery offers a glimmer of hope for the nation where cases have surged and nearly 18 million people have been confirmed to have the disease.

Myanmar‚Äôs military launched air strikes on an area near the Thai border for a second day in a row on April 28, 2021. The junta says it is a response to an attack by ethnic minority Karen insurgents targeting an army post the previous day. The Karen National Union, Myanmar's oldest rebel group, supports the movement that has resisted the junta since it seized power from the civilian-led government. The hostilities near the Salween River in Myanmar‚Äôs eastern Kayin state is described as one of the worst clashes since the February 1 coup.

Brazil, the country with the world‚Äôs second-highest Covid-19 death toll, has seen a growing number of pregnant women, babies and young children dying from the disease. On April 16, 2021, the country asked women to avoid getting pregnant as Brazil fights a more deadly coronavirus variant known as P1. While there is evidence that Covid-19 rarely kills young children, the deaths among young children and babies in Brazil has been linked to the sheer number of cases there. As of April 28, Brazil had recorded a total of 14,441,563 cases and 395,022 deaths.

Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas gave an impassioned speech on television early Friday, during which he announced that he postponed planned parliamentary elections indefinitely.

Speaking from Ramallah, Abbas cited a dispute over voting in Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem as one of the reasons for delaying the elections.

"We decided to postpone the date of the legislative elections until the participation of Jerusalem and its people in this election is guaranteed. Jerusalem does not give up, nor does it relinquish the right of our people in Jerusalem to exercise the right of democracy," said Abbas.

Palestine's authority has been divided and paralysed for 15 years, which is when the last election was held. 

Israel made nor formal announcement on whether it would permit the Palestinian vote to take place in Jerusalem.

TRANSLATIONS:

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "We decided to postpone the date of the legislative elections until the participation of Jerusalem and its people in this election is guaranteed. Jerusalem does not give up, nor does it relinquish the right of our people in Jerusalem to exercise the right of democracy."

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "We're talking about Jerusalem again and again, for the thousandth time. It is Palestine's capital and will continue, regardless of whomever doesn't like it, to support these activities in Jerusalem. Yes, they say, we support this activity, yes we support it, because our people are in danger, and Israel decided to kill the Arabs. They said, 'Kill the Arabs in Jerusalem. We will not allow them to do so.'"

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "We emphasised that holding the elections must include all the Palestinian territories, including Jerusalem as nominations, votes and electoral propaganda. We made multiple attempts, and if you don't do the same, you will face the consequences. Hanna Nasser tried, as did all of us, to go to Jerusalem and trained the young ones multiple times so they can mobilise for the elections." *MULTIPLE SHOTS AT SOURCE*

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "We have made great efforts with the international community in order to oblige the Israeli occupation state to hold it in Jerusalem, but this endeavour has been rejected until the moment. I mean, after an hour the approval is granted, we have no objection to it and I say it in your name." *MULTIPLE SHOTS AT SOURCE*

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "We call on the international community to continue to pressure Israel to stop its aggressive practice, to stop its hand from our legitimate national rights, and to put an end to Israel in order to abide by the signed agreements, including the right of our people in Jerusalem to participate in the elections."

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "We will continue to work to consolidate national unity, end the division, achieve reconciliation, and continue peaceful popular resistance. Please work for a peaceful popular resistance, for God's sake do that. Where is the peaceful popular resistance that we must do?"

SOT, Mahmoud Abbas, President of Palestine (Arabic): "Work to form a national unity government that is committed to international decisions, any time we sit down, us and all organisations, including Hamas and others, meet together. We asked Hamas and they said to him, tomorrow we will respond to you in an answer to the special points in international commitments, and until the moment we await the answer. That we run but in guarantees."

#Palestine #Israel #PalestinianElections #Abbas #EastJerusalem

    Video ID: 20210430-004

    Video on Demand: https://ruptly.tv/videos/20210430-004
    Contact: cd@ruptly.tv    

    Twitter: http://twitter.com/Ruptly
    Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/Ruptly

Mandatory credit: Council of ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria

Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov said the country will order Russia's COVID-19 Sputnik vaccine once the European Medicines Agency approves it, in Sofia on Thursday

"Once the European medical agency say 'yes,' we will sign a contract for import. We only respect the rules. It's not because the it's a Russian vaccine, but because we observe the norm," said Borisov.

"This vaccine (Sputnik) is a substance which is not a medicine. It's used for a prophylaxis and eventual use would contradict to the Bulgarian law for human medicine. Besides that, to be imported in Bulgaria, as the Socialist Party wants it, it must go through the centralised European procedure, established since 2004. For me such import is totally impossible and mostly it would risk the life and health of the Bulgarian citizens. Because the risk rating procedure was not finalised in the EU," added Bulgarian Health Minister Kostadin Angelov.

TRANSLATIONS:

SOT, Boyko Borisov, Bulgarian Prime Minister (Bulgarian): "Once the European medical agency say 'yes,' we will sign a contract for import. We only respect the rules. It's not because the it's a Russian vaccine, but because we observe the norm."

SOT, Kostadin Angelov, Bulgarian Minister of Health (Bulgarian): "This vaccine (Sputnik) is a substance which is not a medicine. It's used for a prophylaxis and eventual use would contradict to the Bulgarian law for human medicine. Besides that, to be imported in Bulgaria, as the Socialist Party wants it, it must go through the centralised European procedure, established since 2004. For me such import is totally impossible and mostly it would risk the life and health of the Bulgarian citizens. Because the risk rating procedure was not finalised in the EU."

Four peregrine falcon chicks were born this spring in one of Barcelona's iconic Sagrada Familia towers.
 
On Thursday, biologists Sergi Garcia and Eduard Durany reached the heights where the chicks live. They then carefully remove them from the nest to perform to treat the wounds caused by an infestation of flies.
 
"It is a species that looks for high places to nest, and particularly in cities these places tend to be quiet places, with the Sagrada Familia being an exception because it is one of the most visited buildings in Spain," said Sergi Garcia. 
 
The fact that the birds have chosen the church towers to build their nests has several advantages for the biologists who monitor the growth of the Peregrine falcon, an endangered bird species.  
 
"We can be on top of the pairs growing in Barcelona more easily than in the wild, in the wild it would be practically impossible to do so because access to the nests is very difficult and complicated, and hereby getting on a lift we can [reach] the nest itself immediately. This is the advantage of breeding in the city," said Eduard Durany. 
 
According to local reports, the four peregrine falcon chicks have brought the number of birds hatched in Barcelona's iconic church to 46. 

TRANSLATIONS:

SOT, Eduard Durany, biologist (Spanish): "We can be on top of the pairs growing in Barcelona more easily than in a natural environment, in the natural environment it would be practically impossible to do that because access to the nests is very difficult and complicated, and hereby getting on a lift we can [reach] the nest itself, immediately. This is the advantage of breeding in the city". 

SOT, Sergi Garcia, biologist (Spanish): "Because it is a species that looks for high places to make its nest, and in cities, these places are usually quiet places too, the Sagrada Familia church being an exception because it is one of the most visited buildings in Spain, and nevertheless this is a pair that has become very used to the presence of people, of visitors, but in general what they look for is tranquillity". 

#Spain #SagradaFamilia #Barcelona #PeregrineFalcon

Four peregrine falcon chicks were born this spring in one of Barcelona's iconic Sagrada Familia towers.
 
On Thursday, biologists Sergi Garcia and Eduard Durany reached the heights where the chicks live. They then carefully remove them from the nest to perform to treat the wounds caused by an infestation of flies.
 
"It is a species that looks for high places to nest, and particularly in cities these places tend to be quiet places, with the Sagrada Familia being an exception because it is one of the most visited buildings in Spain," said Sergi Garcia. 
 
The fact that the birds have chosen the church towers to build their nests has several advantages for the biologists who monitor the growth of the Peregrine falcon, an endangered bird species.  
 
"We can be on top of the pairs growing in Barcelona more easily than in the wild, in the wild it would be practically impossible to do so because access to the nests is very difficult and complicated, and hereby getting on a lift we can [reach] the nest itself immediately. This is the advantage of breeding in the city," said Eduard Durany. 
 
According to local reports, the four peregrine falcon chicks have brought the number of birds hatched in Barcelona's iconic church to 46. 

TRANSLATIONS:

SOT, Eduard Durany, biologist (Spanish): "We can be on top of the pairs growing in Barcelona more easily than in a natural environment, in the natural environment it would be practically impossible to do that because access to the nests is very difficult and complicated, and hereby getting on a lift we can [reach] the nest itself, immediately. This is the advantage of breeding in the city". 

SOT, Sergi Garcia, biologist (Spanish): "Because it is a species that looks for high places to make its nest, and in cities, these places are usually quiet places too, the Sagrada Familia church being an exception because it is one of the most visited buildings in Spain, and nevertheless this is a pair that has become very used to the presence of people, of visitors, but in general what they look for is tranquillity". 

#Spain #SagradaFamilia #Barcelona #PeregrineFalcon

localized.title: Spain: Biologists treat peregrine falcon chicks hatched in Barcelona's iconic Sagrada Familia

Emergency services were deployed from the Galilee Medical Center in Nahariya on early Friday to assist in the treatment of dozens that were injured in a stampede at an overcrowded gathering to celebrate the Lag B‚ÄôOmer Jewish festival in Meron, on Thursday night.

At least 38 people lost their lives in the stampede, according to the rescue services.

The incident took place as tens of thousands of majoritarily ultra-Orthodox Jews were participating in the annual event, around the tomb of Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai, a 2nd-century tannaitic sage.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the incident a ‚Äòheavy disaster.‚Äô

#Israel #MountMeron #LagBaOmer #Stampede

Large hailstones provoked damages on vehicles and houses in Texas, as seen in Tarrant County and Parker County on Thursday.

Cars windows were shattered due to hailstones reported to be as large as a grapefruit, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

A tornado smashed and flipped some mobile homes in Parker County. 

A tornado warning was issued on Wednesday evening in parts of Tarrant County after severe storms hit north and central Texas.

#Texas #ExtremeWeather #GorillaHail

A crowd of protesters gathered for an early Labour Day commemoration at Taksim Square in Istanbul on Thursday.

Various members of worker's unions were present at the march to commemorate the Taksim Square Massacre which took place on May 1, 1977, when leftist demonstrators were the victims of an attack that killed between 34 and 42 people.

"We gathered to commemorate all our comrades, our friends that we lost in the struggle for the liberation of May 1st and Taksim. Exactly 44 years ago, we lost our friends here on May 1, 1977, right in this square. When we gather here after 44 years, we now know that the date of May 1 in this country is not just the history of the liberation of Taksim, the history of the class struggle," said Arzu Cerkezoglu, the president of the Confederation of Progressive Trade Unions of Turkey (DISK).

Protesters held a minute of silence and laid down flowers in tribute to the 1977 victims.

TRANSLATIONS:

SOT, Arzu Cerkezoglu, President of Confederation of Progressive Trade Unions of Turkey (DISK) (Turkish): "We gathered to commemorate all our comrades, our friends that we lost in the struggle for the liberation of May 1st and Taksim. Exactly 44 years ago, we lost our friends here on May 1, 1977, right in this square. When we gather here after 44 years, we now know that the date of May 1 in this country is not just the history of the liberation of Taksim, the history of the class struggle."

SOT, Aysun Gezen, KESK president (Turkish): "We are here to take over the flag of struggle from where they fell and carry it to the future, to build a more equal and free country, a world where labourers also rule."

#Turkey #TaksimSquare #May1 #LabourDay 

    Video ID: 20210429-072

    Video on Demand: https://ruptly.tv/videos/20210429-072
    Contact: cd@ruptly.tv

snippet.description:
Subscribe to our channel! rupt.ly/subscribe

Istanbul locals and store owners condemned Turkey's 17-day ban on alcohol sales as part of a new lockdown measure, on Thursday.

"I don't see what the alcohol ban has to do with the pandemic. After all, does alcohol produce crowds? People can take it and drink it at home. I find it ridiculous," said Necati Esengul, a store employee.

Another store worker echoed Esengul's statement, saying that "sales are going to be very affected. We don't know what we are going to do for 17 days. Does it have anything to do with the pandemic?"

"Why are you locking people up and banning alcohol? People who can't go out started to come up with alternatives, and now they're making alcohol themselves at home. You can't stop it. Turkey is a secular country, that's how it's come to be so far," deplored Hikmet Selvi, a local.

As a result of the ban, the hashtag #alkolumedokunma ('Don't touch my alcohol') trended on Twitter in Turkey, with social media users accusing the decision of the government to be politically motivated.

According to data compiled by John Hopkins University, Turkey has registered a total of 4,788,700 COVID-19 cases and 38,737 related deaths as of Thursday.

TRANSLATIONS:

SOT, Hikmet Selvi, Local (Turkish): "Why are you locking people up and banning alcohol? People who can't go out started to come up with alternatives, and now they're making alcohol themselves at home. You can't stop it. Turkey is a secular country, that's how it's come to be so far. They're taking the opportunity to tell people, 'Get your head together, look, we're banning alcohol and stuff, we're constantly raising cigarette prices, you're still drinking,' but it can't go on like this."

SOT, Eser Guven, Store employee (Turkish): "Sales are going to be very affected. We don't know what we are going to do for 17 days. Does it have anything to do with the pandemic? And there's no explanation approved by scientists. It's a decision made on their own."

SOT, Necati Esengul, Store employee (Turkish): "I don't see what the alcohol ban has to do with the pandemic. After all, does alcohol produce crowds? People can take it and drink it at home. I find it ridiculous, I don't think this prohibition of alcohol makes any sense. We're done, so we don't know what to do."

SOT, Ergin Hosver, Local (Turkish): "I've never smoked or drunk alcohol in my life, and now I'm thinking about starting alcohol. Could something like this happen? It's a purely political decision. It's a decision that's disgusting. We're embarrassing ourselves in front of the whole world. It's ridiculous. The top government is shutting down the thing that's most taxed, and that's even more ridiculous. I mean, at what period was alcohol banned?"

SOT, Ali Abbasaga, Store employee (Turkish): "This decision does not affect us in a positive way. It's going to affect us badly, I'll tell you, the tradesmen are already in trouble, and this is going to be the cherry on top. It has nothing to do with the pandemic. What's that got to do with anything? The citizen's going to buy it and drink it at his house. Are there any people left on the street, outside? I don't understand that."

#Turkey #Lockdown #Alcohol #Erdogan #Alkolumedokunma

    Video ID: 20210429-073

    Video on Demand: https://ruptly.tv/videos/20210429-073
    Contact: cd@ruptly.tv    

    Twitter: http://twitter.com/Ruptly
    Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/Ruptly

snippet.description:
"Bonus Edit" of previously unused footage from the 145th Anniversary Re-enactment of the Second Day Battle of Gettysburg Re-enactment which took place on July 5th 2008.  "Hold The Line" - The Battle for the Peach Orchard portrays the July 2nd 1863 actions of the battle.  The majority of this footage ended up on the cutting-room-floor and wasn't originally included in the Docu-Drama DVD we produced for the event.

No narration, just some of the best bits of Re-enactment footage we captured on the field in a 'combat cameraman' style. It's like our version of a Civil War ASMR video!

For education, entertainment, enlightenment and inspiration.  We hope you enjoy and even learn something.  Never forget!

snippet.description:
Spokesperson Ned Price leads the Department Press Briefing, at the Department of State.

0:00 Livestream preview
1:15:34 Spokesperson Price addresses the press
1:17:28‚Äã Spokesperson Price responds to questions
---------------
Under the leadership of the President and Secretary of State, the U.S. Department of State leads America‚Äôs foreign policy through diplomacy, advocacy, and assistance by advancing the interests of the American people, their safety and economic prosperity. On behalf of the American people we promote and demonstrate democratic values and advance a free, peaceful, and prosperous world.

The Secretary of State, appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, is the President's chief foreign affairs adviser. The Secretary carries out the President's foreign policies through the State Department, which includes the Foreign Service, Civil Service and U.S. Agency for International Development.

Get updates from the U.S. Department of State at www.state.gov and on social media!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/statedept 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/StateDept 
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/statedept
Flickr: https://www.flickr.com/photos/stateph...

Subscribe to the State Department Blog: https://www.state.gov/blogs
Watch on-demand State Department videos: https://video.state.gov/

State Department website: https://www.state.gov/
Careers website: https://careers.state.gov/
White House website: https://www.whitehouse.gov/

#StateDepartment #DepartmentofState #Diplomacy

snippet.description:
US President Joe Biden has given his first address to Congress, on the eve of his 100th day in office. Biden has credited his administration with rolling out an effective COVID-19 vaccination campaign. He's also highlighted the financial assistance provided to working families, struggling with the economic fallout of the pandemic. The US president has used the address to introduce his more progressive agenda on police reforms and the climate crisis, urging lawmakers to work with the White House to pass those bills. Yasmine El-Sabawi reports from Washington.
#BidenPresidency

snippet.description:
Gro Intelligence CEO Sara Menker's childhood imprinted a profound sense of how easily life can be disrupted by catastrophic forces, and the importance of preparing for looming disaster. That worldview and her commodities-trader background inspired Menker in 2014 to found Gro Intelligence, a startup that uses artificial intelligence and machine learning to help confront two of the biggest challenges faced by humanity: food security and climate change. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about getting ready for disaster,‚Äù says Menker. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about hedging for the downside risk.‚Äù The timing is excellent for a company focused on forecasting and managing climate disaster. In the U.S. alone last year, there were a record 22 climate-related disasters with losses exceeding $1 billion each. In all, the droughts, cyclones, wildfires and storms combined for a staggering $95 billion in damage. With such headlines fresh in the minds of investors, in January Gro raised $85 million. Backers include prominent tech investors Intel Capital and Africa Internet Ventures (a strategic partnership between TPG Growth and EchoVC). Menker is one of the handful of Black female founders who have the potential to achieve unicorn status, the term applied to startups valued at $1 billion or more.

Read more about Gro Intelligence : https://time.com/collection/time100-companies/5950007/gro-intelligence/

snippet.description:
Mary Barra has been leading General Motors on a quest that, if successful, will be one of the most consequential reinventions in corporate history. GM is playing serious catchup in the electric-vehicle game, and success is far from certain for the legacy carmaker that sold fewer than 21,000 EVs in the U.S. last year. 

Barra, the daughter of a GM auto-worker who herself started at GM inspecting fenders, is a rare CEO who has spent her entire career with one company. She recently joined TIME for several conversations on GM‚Äôs plan to invest $27 billion in EVs and introduce 30 new models by 2025‚Äîand its ‚Äúaspiration‚Äù to quit making cars with tailpipes by 2035.

Read more about General Motors : https://ti.me/3aPG2TY

snippet.description:
Reese Witherspoon, 45, has transformed her role in Hollywood from movie star to business leader‚Äîand maker of her own fortune. After rising as a child actor, she shot to household-name status for 2001‚Äôs Legally Blonde, going on to win an Oscar in 2006 for Walk the Line. But even after those triumphs, for a time she struggled to find satisfying roles in Hollywood, where women‚Äôs stories have long been sidelined. She discovered a way to change that in a lifelong love: books. Celebrating books through her book club‚Äîand adapting them for the screen‚Äîis now the foundation of Witherspoon‚Äôs business at Hello Sunshine, the media company she founded in 2016, where she‚Äôs established a track record for spotting, and making, hits.

Read more about Hello Sunshine: https://time.com/collection/time100-companies/5953581/hello-sunshine/

snippet.description:
The F-15EX is a ready-now replacement for the F-15C that includes best-in-class payload, range and speed. Designed to deliver value to the U.S. Air Force, the F-15EX will be a backbone fighter for the service ‚Äì not just today, but for the next several decades.

The Air Force placed its first order for the F-15EX in July 2020, awarding a contract for the first lot of eight jets with a value not to exceed about $1.2 billion. All of those aircraft are set to be delivered to Eglin AFB by fiscal 2023.

snippet.description:
ÿßŸÑŸÜŸÉÿ®ÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸäÿ© ŸÑŸÖ ÿ™ÿ®ÿØÿ£ ÿπÿßŸÖ 1948ÿå Ÿàÿ•ŸÜŸÖÿß ŸÇÿ®ŸÑ ÿ∞ŸÑŸÉ ÿ®ŸÉÿ´Ÿäÿ±ÿå ŸÅŸÅŸä ÿπÿßŸÖ 1910 ÿ£ÿ®ÿ±ŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿµŸÜÿØŸàŸÇ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸàŸÖŸä ÿßŸÑŸäŸáŸàÿØŸä ÿµŸÅŸÇÿ© ÿ¥ÿ±ÿßÿ° ÿ£ŸÉÿ´ÿ± ŸÖŸÜ ŸÖÿßÿ¶ÿ™Ÿä ÿ£ŸÑŸÅ ÿØŸàŸÜŸÖ ŸÖŸÜ ÿ£ÿ±ÿßÿ∂Ÿä ÿ≥ŸáŸÑ ŸÖÿ±ÿ¨ ÿßÿ®ŸÜ ÿπÿßŸÖÿ± ŸÖÿπ ÿ•ÿ≠ÿØŸâ ÿßŸÑÿπÿßÿ¶ŸÑÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ•ŸÇÿ∑ÿßÿπŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÑÿ®ŸÜÿßŸÜŸäÿ©ÿå ŸàŸÇÿØ ÿ™ŸÖÿÆÿ∂ ÿπŸÜ ÿ™ŸÑŸÉ ÿßŸÑÿµŸÅŸÇÿ© ÿ™Ÿáÿ¨Ÿäÿ± ÿ£ŸÉÿ´ÿ± ŸÖŸÜ ÿ≥ÿ™ŸäŸÜ ÿ£ŸÑŸÅ ŸÅŸÑÿßÿ≠ ŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸäÿå ŸÖŸÖÿß ŸäÿπŸÜŸä ÿ£ŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿáÿ¨Ÿäÿ± ÿßŸÑŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸä ÿ≠ÿµŸÑ ŸÖÿπ ÿ®ÿØÿßŸäÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÇÿ±ŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿπÿ¥ÿ±ŸäŸÜ.

Ÿäÿ®ŸäŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÅŸäŸÑŸÖ ÿ£ŸÜ ŸÖŸÇÿßŸàŸÖÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ¥ÿ±Ÿàÿπ ÿßŸÑÿµŸáŸäŸàŸÜŸä ÿ®ÿØÿ£ÿ™ ÿ£Ÿäÿ∂ÿß ŸÖÿ®ŸÉÿ±ÿßÿå ŸÉÿ™Ÿáÿ¨Ÿäÿ± ÿßŸÑŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸäŸäŸÜÿå ÿπŸÜÿØŸÖÿß ÿ±ÿßÿ≠ÿ™ ÿ™ÿ™ÿ¥ŸÉŸÑ ŸÖÿ¨ŸÖŸàÿπÿßÿ™ ŸÖŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿ´Ÿàÿßÿ± ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿßÿ∑ŸÇ ÿßŸÑÿ±ŸäŸÅŸäÿ©ÿå ŸÑŸäÿ™ÿ±ÿßŸÅŸÇ ÿ∞ŸÑŸÉ ŸÖÿπ ÿÆÿ±Ÿàÿ¨ ŸÖÿ∏ÿßŸáÿ±ÿßÿ™ ÿ≠ÿßÿ¥ÿØÿ© ÿ∂ÿØ Ÿáÿ¨ÿ±ÿ© ÿßŸÑÿµŸáÿßŸäŸÜÿ© ÿπÿßŸÖ 1921 ŸàŸÑÿ™ÿ™ÿ∑Ÿàÿ± ÿ™ŸÑŸÉ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ∏ÿßŸáÿ±ÿßÿ™ ŸàÿßŸÑÿßÿ≠ÿ™ÿ¨ÿßÿ¨ÿßÿ™ ÿ•ŸÑŸâ ŸÖŸàÿßÿ¨Ÿáÿßÿ™ ÿØÿßŸÖŸäÿ© ÿ®ŸÑÿ∫ÿ™ ÿ£Ÿàÿ¨Ÿáÿß ÿπÿßŸÖ 1929 ŸÅŸä "ÿ´Ÿàÿ±ÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ±ÿßŸÇ"ÿå ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ≠ŸàŸÉŸÖ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ•ÿ´ÿ±Ÿáÿß ÿßŸÑÿπÿ¥ÿ±ÿßÿ™ ŸÖŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸäŸäŸÜ ÿ®ÿ£ÿ≠ŸÉÿßŸÖ ŸÖÿ™ŸÅÿßŸàÿ™ÿ©ÿå ŸÖŸÜ ÿ®ŸäŸÜŸáÿß ÿ•ÿπÿØÿßŸÖ ÿ´ŸÑÿßÿ´ÿ© ŸÖŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿ´Ÿàÿßÿ± ŸÅŸä ÿ≥ÿ¨ŸÜ ÿπŸÉÿß: ŸÖÿ≠ŸÖÿØ ÿ¨ŸÖÿ¨ŸàŸÖ ŸàŸÅÿ§ÿßÿØ ÿ≠ÿ¨ÿßÿ≤Ÿä Ÿàÿπÿ∑ÿß ÿßŸÑÿ≤Ÿäÿ±.

Ÿäÿ¥ÿ™ŸÖŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿ¨ÿ≤ÿ° ÿßŸÑÿ£ŸàŸÑ ŸÖŸÜ ÿ≥ŸÑÿ≥ŸÑÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÜŸÉÿ®ÿ© ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÖÿßÿØÿ© ÿ∫ŸÜŸäÿ© ÿ™ÿ¥ŸÖŸÑ ŸÖÿ≠ÿßŸàÿ± ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ÿ© ŸàŸÅÿ±ÿπŸäÿ©ÿå ŸÖŸÜŸáÿß: ÿ£ÿ∑ŸÖÿßÿπ ÿßŸÑÿ∫ÿ±ÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿßÿ±ŸäÿÆŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ®Ÿäÿ™ÿ© ÿ®ÿØÿ°ÿß ÿ®ŸÖÿ≠ÿßŸàŸÑÿ© ŸÜÿßÿ®ŸÑŸäŸàŸÜ ÿ®ŸàŸÜÿßÿ®ÿ±ÿ™ ÿßÿ≠ÿ™ŸÑÿßŸÑ ÿπŸÉÿß ÿπÿßŸÖ 1799ÿå ÿ´ŸÖ ŸÜÿ¥Ÿàÿ° ŸÅŸÉÿ±ÿ© ÿßŸÑÿØŸàŸÑÿ© ÿßŸÑŸäŸáŸàÿØŸäÿ© ŸàÿπŸÖŸÑ ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ∏ŸÖÿ© ÿßŸÑÿµŸáŸäŸàŸÜŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑÿπÿßŸÑŸÖŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑÿØÿ§Ÿàÿ® ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ™ÿ≠ŸÇŸäŸÇŸáÿßÿå Ÿàÿ£ÿÆŸäÿ±ÿß ÿπÿØŸÖ Ÿàÿ¨ŸàÿØ ŸÜÿÆÿ® ŸÇŸäÿßÿØŸäÿ© ÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ© ŸÇÿßÿØÿ±ÿ© ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÖŸÇÿßÿ±ÿπÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÜÿÆÿ® ÿßŸÑŸäŸáŸàÿØŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ•ŸÖÿ®ÿ±ÿßÿ∑Ÿàÿ±Ÿäÿ© ŸÖÿ´ŸÑ Ÿáÿ±ÿ®ÿ±ÿ™ ÿµŸÖŸàÿ¶ŸäŸÑÿå Ÿàÿ≠ÿßŸäŸäŸÖ ŸàÿßŸäÿ≤ŸÖŸÜÿå ŸÅŸÇÿØ ŸÉÿßŸÜÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸäÿßÿØÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ≥Ÿäÿßÿ≥Ÿäÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸäÿ© ŸÇŸäÿßÿØÿ© ÿ™ŸÇŸÑŸäÿØŸäÿ© ŸÇÿßÿ¶ŸÖÿ© ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ™Ÿàÿßÿ±ÿ´ ŸÖŸÜÿßÿµÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ≤ÿπÿßŸÖÿ©.

ŸÇÿßŸÑ ŸÖÿØŸäÿ± ŸàŸÉÿßŸÑÿ© ÿßŸÑÿßÿ≥ÿ™ÿÆÿ®ÿßÿ±ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿØŸÅÿßÿπŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ£ŸÖÿ±ŸäŸÉŸäÿ© ÿ≥ŸÉŸàÿ™ ÿ®Ÿäÿ±ŸäŸàÿ± ÿ•ŸÜ ÿ•Ÿäÿ±ÿßŸÜ ÿ™ÿ¥ŸÉŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ≠ÿØŸä ÿßŸÑÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥Ÿä ŸÑŸÖÿµÿßŸÑÿ≠ ÿ®ŸÑÿßÿØŸá ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑÿ¥ÿ±ŸÇ ÿßŸÑÿ£Ÿàÿ≥ÿ∑
Ÿàÿ£Ÿàÿ∂ÿ≠ÿå ÿÆŸÑÿßŸÑ ÿ¨ŸÑÿ≥ÿ© ÿßÿ≥ÿ™ŸÖÿßÿπ ŸÑŸÑÿ¨ŸÜÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÇŸàÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≥ŸÑÿ≠ÿ© ÿ®ŸÖÿ¨ŸÑÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿ¥ŸäŸàÿÆ ÿßŸÑÿ£ŸÖÿ±ŸäŸÉŸäÿå ÿ£ŸÜ ÿ•Ÿäÿ±ÿßŸÜ ÿ™ŸÖÿ™ŸÑŸÉ ŸÇÿØÿ±ÿßÿ™ ÿπÿ≥ŸÉÿ±Ÿäÿ© ŸÖÿ™ÿ∑Ÿàÿ±ÿ©ÿå Ÿàÿ™ÿ®ÿØŸä ÿßÿ≥ÿ™ÿπÿØÿßÿØŸáÿß ŸÑÿßÿ≥ÿ™ÿÆÿØÿßŸÖ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸàÿ© ÿ∂ÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸàÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ£ŸÖÿ±ŸäŸÉŸäÿ© Ÿàÿ¥ÿ±ŸÉÿßÿ¶Ÿáÿß.

snippet.description:
Khrysantemum-S is the most advanced Russian anti-tank missile system. Its tests are taking place in Kolomna, near Moscow, on the basis of the test training of the Mechanical Engineering Design Bureau. Industry representatives test complexes at all types of targets: tanks, helicopters, concrete fortifications and enemy manpower. Khrysantema-S is the most powerful anti-tank missile system in the world. Based on the chassis of the new Russian BMP-3 infantry fighting vehicle, the Khrysantema mobile launcher can move with equal ease off-road at a speed of 70 km/h, as well as force rivers and other water obstacles.

snippet.description:
The reality on the ground for many in Myanmar is bleak as they see no end to the violence that arrived with the military coup. 

‚ÄúOur futures expectations suddenly disappear," says a journalist in Yangon, "and just going out isn't totally safe anymore. You are in constant worry if the police or army might suddenly arrest you.‚Äù

The military says it wants a true and disciplined democracy, after claiming widespread fraud in last year's general election. It has promised to hold "free and fair" elections but the state of emergency's come at an extreme cost.

Since overthrowing the civilian-led government, the junta has killed more than 750 protesters throughout the country with nearly 3,500 others detained or sentenced to prison, according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners.

‚ÄúIf this continues, we don‚Äôt expect to have a future any more," says a banker who lives in Yangon, "it‚Äôs possible that what we dare not think will happen."

"What makes our concerns and fears worse is the possibility of a civil war like in Syria. I think this will lead to a dark age for our future generations.‚Äù

Subscribe to our YouTube channel: https://bit.ly/2TwO8Gm

snippet.description:
As India grapples with the fast spreading coronavirus pandemic, a COVID-19 positive man decided to get married.

The wedding ceremony took place in Ratlam, in Madhya Pradesh.

The bride and the groom and rest of the family members wore PPE (personal protective equipment) kits as a priest also in PPE recited sacred verses and performed the wedding rituals on Monday.

The wedding took place after getting permission from the government.

According to Shyam Lal, the father of the groom, his son was infected a few days before the wedding, but was asymptomatic.

India set another global record in new virus cases Thursday, as millions of people in one state cast votes despite rising infections and the country geared up to open its vaccination rollout to all adults amid snags.

With 379,257 new infections, India now has reported more than 18.3 million cases, second only to the United States.

The Health Ministry also reported 3,645 deaths in the last 24 hours, bringing the total to 204,832. Experts believe both figures are an undercount, but it's unclear by how much.  

India has set a daily global record for seven of the past eight days, with a seven-day moving average of nearly 350,000 infections.

Daily deaths have nearly tripled in the past three weeks, reflecting the intensity of the latest surge. And the country's already teetering health system is under immense strain, prompting multiple allies to send help.

snippet.description:
(Apr. 29) The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has moved to ban the sale of menthol cigarettes, citing their disproportionate effect on the health of African Americans.

The FDA announced today that it‚Äôs ‚Äúworking toward issuing proposed product standards within the next year to ban menthol‚Äù as a flavor in cigarettes. It also plans to ban all flavors, including menthol, in cigars. The FDA said it is ‚Äúmoving expeditiously‚Äù and that its next step will be to publish proposed rules in the Federal Register, allowing an opportunity for public comment.

‚ÄúBanning menthol -- the last allowable flavor -- in cigarettes and banning all flavors in cigars will help save lives, particularly among those disproportionately affected by these deadly products,‚Äù Acting FDA Commissioner Janet Woodcock said in the statement. She said it would address health disparities in communities of color and in low-income populations.

The move comes after more than a decade of inaction. Congress first recommended in 2009 that the agency decide what to do about menthol flavoring in cigarettes, which gives them a minty taste and soothes the throat but can make smoking more addictive, anti-tobacco groups say.

---

snippet.description:
Germany, France and other European Union governments called on the rest of the bloc to join them in curbing travel from India as the country struggles to cope with record levels of Covid-19 infections.

At a meeting of ambassadors on Wednesday, several officials expressed concern over the risk of possible coronavirus variants in India triggering a fourth wave in Europe and urged the EU to quickly adopt restrictions, according to a diplomatic note seen by Bloomberg.

During the same meeting, the European Commission said it would soon propose an emergency mechanism to allow the bloc to rapidly address the arrival of new strains. The commission said it had asked the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control to look at variants of concern and come up with criteria and mapping to allow for coordinated decisions about how to respond. Some member states welcomed the idea, the note says.

snippet.description:
This film is about the famous Qutub Minar-a UNESCO World Heritage Site and symbolic marker of the city of Delhi.

It explores various histories, myths, legends and everyday meanings associated with this remarkable historic building which transform it into a perfect site of memory 

The film takes the Qutub complex as a reference point to raise a few very base questions.

Is it really important to define the religion of historic buildings? Does it mean that every minaret is Muslim and every idol is Hindu? How does this fixed imagination of history that divides India's past into Hindi and Muslim contribution to the communal conflicts?

How do we look at the process of monumentalisation that transforms old buildings/ruins into officially declared Protected Monuments of National Importance? How does this official recognition affect the symbolic status of Qutub Minar as a monument?

 Do common people care about the controversial histories of this building?

The film encourages an informal convention on history, myth politics and popular culture so that we can draw our own meanings of Qutub!

snippet.description:
China Panic: UK aircraft carrier to sail through the South China Sea amid high tension between US and China

HMS Queen Elizabeth and her Carrier Strike Group will sail through the South China Sea despite Chinese warnings, and it has been confirmed.

China claims almost all of the 1.3 million-square-mile South China Sea as its sovereign territory, and it has denounced the presence of foreign warships there as the root of tensions in the region.

One of the first things we will do with the two new colossal aircraft carriers that we have just built is sent them on a freedom of navigation operation to this area, to vindicate our belief in the rules-based international system and in the freedom of navigation through those waterways which are absolutely vital for world trade.

Twitter: https://bit.ly/2YrTTsK
Youtube: https://bit.ly/30odYme
Facebook: https://bit.ly/2MIMG1V

snippet.description:
The world‚Äôs longest pedestrian suspension bridge has been completed in Portugal. The bridge, Arouca 516, sits 175 metres above the River Paiva in the north of the country. Its 516 metre-long walkway breaks the record previously held by the Charles Kuonen Bridge in the Swiss Alps. Located near the tiny town of Arouca and within the Unesco-recognised Arouca Geopark, the bridge took two years to construct and is held up by steel cables and two large towers on each side 
World‚Äôs longest pedestrian suspension bridge opens in Portugal

The World Health Organization (WHO) said the kind of struggle India was having against a devastating resurgence in Covid cases could happen anywhere in the world, during a briefing on Thursday.

Subscribe to Guardian News on YouTube ‚ñ∫ http://bit.ly/guardianwiressub

Hans Kluge, the WHO regional director for Europe, said relaxing measures and allowing mass gatherings should be avoided, especially where vaccination coverage was low and there were contagious variants. The B.1.617 coronavirus variant ‚Äì thought to be partly responsible for India's crisis ‚Äì is now considered a 'variant of interest' by the WHO

snippet.description:
Alexei Navalny has made his first public appearance since staging a 24-day hunger strike. Navalny, who was fined 850,000 roubles (¬£8,200) in February for defaming a second world war veteran who backed a 'reset' of  Vladimir Putin‚Äôs presidential terms, has said the case against him was concocted to further damage his reputation among Russians. 

Subscribe to Guardian News on YouTube ‚ñ∫ http://bit.ly/guardianwiressub

In a courtroom speech, Navalny accused the government of turning 'Russians into slaves' and called Putin a 'naked king', a reference to Hans Christian Andersen‚Äôs folktale The Emperor‚Äôs New Clothes. 

Navalny is serving a two-and-a-half-year sentence on an embezzlement conviction from 2013. He was arrested in January upon his return to Russia from Germany, where he had spent five months recovering from a nerve agent poisoning he blames on the Kremlin ‚Äì accusations Russian officials reject.

Alexei Navalny looks gaunt as he appears in court after hunger strike ‚ñ∫ https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/apr/29/alexei-navalny-looks-gaunt-as-he-appears-in-court-after-hunger-strike

The vaccine deployment minister, Nadhim Zahawi, has defended the UK prime minister, Boris Johnson, over the flat refurbishment row. Zahawi said: 'The prime minister has been very clear that he has paid for this, that he also followed ministerial codes, took advice, and if Lord Geidt in his investigation requires the prime minister to make any other declarations, then he will also do that.'

Joe Biden argued that 'America is on the move again' in his first address to Congress, on the eve of his 100th day in office. The president, flanked by two women¬†‚Äì Vice-President Kamala Harris and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi ‚Äì for the first time in US history, addressed the coronavirus pandemic, the 6 January assault on the Capitol, plans to raise the minimum wage, police reform, climate change and historic levels of investment in the country. Due to social distancing measures, only 200 people, mainly politicians, attended¬†rather than the usual 1,600 guests

snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday thanked Russian President Vladimir Putin for extending help and support to India in its fight against COVID-19.

In a telephonic conversation with the Russian President, PM Modi said the prompt Russian support to India was a symbol of our enduring partnership.

Russia has sent more than 22 tons of humanitarian aid to India, which include oxygen-producing equipment, artificial lung ventilation devices, medical monitors and medicine packages.

In his conversation with the Prime Minister, President Putin expressed solidarity with the people of India and assured that Russia would extend all possible support to respond to the crisis.

Besides, the two leaders also reviewed the diverse bilateral cooperation between both countries and agreed to establish a 2+2 ministerial dialogue between foreign ministers and defence ministers to add further momentum to the bilateral strategic partnership.

Russia will only be the fourth country with which India has such a mechanism of a 2+2 dialogue - the others being the US, Japan and Australia.

On The Big picture today, we will try and understand from experts how significant is this move and how is it going to add further momentum to India-Russia partnership

Anchor/ producer: Teena Jha 

 Guests : 

Dr. Sreeram Chaulia, Foreign Affairs Expert  

Vishnu Prakash, Former Ambassador

snippet.description:
On the first day (April 28), 1.33 Crore people registered for vaccination in the Cowin portal on Wednesday. The portal handled more than 50 thousand Application Program Interface (APIs) calls per second. The vaccination for people 18 years and above will begin on Saturday (May 1).
The Government said Co-WIN digital platform continues to work without any technical glitch on the first day of registration of the expanded eligible population groups.

There will be no walk-in vaccinations in the third phase. All adults who are eligible for the shots will have to register on the CoWIN portal or Aarogya Setu.

In this episode we discuss the government's preparedness ahead of the vaccination day.

GUESTS

a: Dr. Dhruva Chaudhry, State Nodal Officer for Covid, Haryana

b: Abhishek Singh, CEO, MyGov & NEGD, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology, GoI

Exit polls from West Bengal have now come to light and the numbers suggest that the fight is very close. Some have feared victory for the BJP while some have favored the ruling TMC. #ÿ™ŸÑŸÅÿ≤ŸäŸàŸÜ_ÿ≥Ÿàÿ±Ÿäÿß 
ŸÇÿßŸÑÿ™ ŸÖÿµÿßÿØÿ± ŸÖÿ≠ŸÑŸäÿ© ŸÑÿ™ŸÑŸÅÿ≤ŸäŸàŸÜ ÿ≥Ÿàÿ±Ÿäÿßÿå ÿ•ŸÜ ŸÖŸäŸÑŸäÿ¥Ÿäÿßÿ™ ÿ•Ÿäÿ±ÿßŸÜŸäÿ© ÿßÿ™ŸÅŸÇÿ™ ŸÖÿπ ŸÇŸàÿßÿ™ ŸÜÿ∏ÿßŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ≥ÿØ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ±ŸÅÿπ ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿµÿßŸÜÿ© ÿπŸÜ ÿπÿØÿØ ŸÖŸÜ ÿπŸÜÿßÿµÿ±Ÿáÿß ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≠ŸÑŸäŸäŸÜÿå ÿ•ÿ∂ÿßŸÅÿ© ÿ•ŸÑŸâ ŸÜŸäÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÖŸäŸÑŸäÿ¥Ÿäÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ•Ÿäÿ±ÿßŸÜŸäÿ© ŸÅÿµŸÑ Ÿáÿ§ŸÑÿßÿ° ÿßŸÑÿπŸÜÿßÿµÿ±.
ÿ£ŸÑŸÇŸâ ÿ¨Ÿáÿßÿ≤ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿÆÿßÿ®ÿ±ÿßÿ™ ŸÅŸä ŸÇŸàÿßÿ™ ÿ≥Ÿàÿ±Ÿäÿß ÿßŸÑÿØŸäŸÖŸÇÿ±ÿßÿ∑Ÿäÿ© ÿ®ŸÖÿØŸäŸÜÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÖÿ¥ŸÑŸä ÿßŸÑŸÇÿ®ÿ∂ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ£ÿ≠ÿØ ŸÖŸàÿ∏ŸëŸÅŸä ŸáŸäÿ¶ÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≠ÿ±ŸàŸÇÿßÿ™ ŸàÿßŸÑŸÖÿ¥ÿ±ŸÅ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ•ÿØÿßÿ±ÿ© "ÿ≥ÿßÿØŸÉŸàÿ®"ÿå ÿ®ÿ™ŸáŸÖÿ© ÿßÿÆÿ™ŸÑÿßÿ≥Ÿá ŸÖÿπ ÿ¢ÿÆÿ±ŸäŸÜ ŸÖÿß Ÿäÿ≤ŸäÿØ ÿπŸÑŸâ ŸÖŸÑŸäÿßÿ± ÿØŸàŸÑÿßÿ± ÿ£ŸÖŸäÿ±ŸÉŸä ŸÖŸÜ ÿπÿßÿ¶ÿØÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÜŸÅÿ∑. ŸàŸáŸà ÿ£ŸÖÿ± ŸäŸÅÿ≥ÿ± ÿ≠ÿßŸÑÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ≥ÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ™ŸÅÿßŸÇŸÖÿ© ŸÅŸä ÿµŸÅŸàŸÅ ŸÖÿ≥ÿ§ŸàŸÑŸä "ÿßŸÑÿ•ÿØÿßÿ±ÿ©" ŸàŸÉÿ∞ŸÑŸÉ ÿßŸÜÿπÿØÿßŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿÆÿØŸÖÿßÿ™ ŸÅŸä ŸÖŸÜÿßÿ∑ŸÇ ÿ≥Ÿäÿ∑ÿ±ÿ™Ÿáÿß ÿ±ÿ∫ŸÖ Ÿàÿ¨ŸàÿØ ŸÖŸàÿßÿ±ÿØ Ÿáÿßÿ¶ŸÑÿ©.
ÿ£ŸÅÿßÿØÿ™ ŸÖÿµÿßÿØÿ± ÿÆÿßÿµÿ© ŸÑÿ™ŸÑŸÅÿ≤ŸäŸàŸÜ ÿ≥Ÿàÿ±Ÿäÿß ÿ®ÿ£ŸÜ "ÿ™ÿ¨ÿßÿ±ÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿ¥Ÿäÿ¥)ÿßŸÑŸÇŸÜÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ£ŸÅÿ∫ÿßŸÜŸä(ÿßÿ≤ÿØÿßÿØÿ™ ÿ®ÿ¥ŸÉŸÑ Ÿàÿßÿ∂ÿ≠ ŸÖŸÜÿ∞ ŸÖÿ∑ŸÑÿπ ŸÜŸäÿ≥ÿßŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿßŸÑŸäÿå ŸàŸÑŸàÿ≠ÿ∏ ÿßÿ±ÿ™ŸÅÿßÿπ ŸÖÿπÿØŸÑÿßÿ™ ÿ≤ÿ±ÿßÿπÿ™Ÿá ŸÅŸä ÿ±ŸäŸÅ ÿ≠ŸÖÿµ ÿßŸÑÿ¨ŸÜŸàÿ®Ÿä Ÿà ÿßŸÑÿ¥ÿ±ŸÇŸä ÿ≠Ÿäÿ´ ÿ™ŸÜÿ™ÿ¥ÿ± ÿ£ÿ±ÿßÿ∂ ÿÆÿµÿ®ÿ© ŸàÿØÿ±ÿ¨ÿßÿ™ ÿ≠ÿ±ÿßÿ±ÿ© ŸÖÿ±ÿ™ŸÅÿπÿ© ŸÜÿ≥ÿ®Ÿäÿß Ÿàÿ±ÿ∑Ÿàÿ®ÿ© ŸÇŸÑŸäŸÑÿ©" .

snippet.description:
U.S. Air Force Special Tactics Airmen with the 22nd Special Tactics Squadron infiltrate and exfiltrate a Team McChord C-17 Globemaster III during Exercise Rainier War at Joint Base Lewis-McChord, Washington.

Rainier War tests the 62nd Airlift Wing's capability to plan, generate and execute a deployment tasking, sustain contingency operations, demonstrate full spectrum readiness while executing agile combat employment in a contested, degraded and operationally limited environment.

snippet.description:
Across the planet, the incredible animals of our world birth and raise their young in very different ways. The African Wildcat has to survive amongst some apex predators even at few days old, but it's not the only young animal that faces adversity from birth.

Subscribe to Pets & Vets to watch more documentaries: http://bit.ly/2MrUEPS

Zoologist Martin Hughes-Games follows the dedicated and inspirational individuals working to save some very special babies who are the lifeline to preserving some of our planet's most critically vulnerable species.

Content licensed from Off The Fence to Little Dot Studios.

Any queries, please contact us at: owned-enquiries@littledotstudios.com

#Pets&Vets #NaturesBabies

00:00 Introduction
05:37 Black Mamba
08:43 African Wildcat
19:19 Foam Nest Frog
24:24 Baboon Infant
33:20 Wildebeast
40:26 Hippopotamus
45:21 Giraffe calf

snippet.description:
The 100-day marker, which was first used during the presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt, has been the standard to gauge a president's immediate progress. President Joe Biden entered office in January with the goal to tamp down a raging pandemic, fix a broken economy that left millions unemployed and reestablish the trans-Atlantic relationship.

President Biden's first major promise was to ensure that he would administer 100 million shots in his first 100 days. Once seen as an overly ambitious goal, he passed that mark after 58 days in office. In March, he raised the target to 200 million shots in arms, which he reached seven days before the 100 day-mark. In the US, 29% of the population has been fully vaccinated and over 40% have at least been given one shot.

Biden has had to walk a tightrope when it comes to foreign policy. The stormy relationship that the Trump administration had with longtime allies has been more fluid since he entered office in January. Biden has put an emphasis on reconnecting with the US's previous allies, like the EU. Biden's remarks at the Munich Security Conference and Secretary of State Antony Blinken's two separate trips to Brussels to meet with NATO allies have been an indication that they are making serious attempts to reconnect the trans-Atlantic alliance.

Biden moved quickly by sticking to his promise to reenter the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement, which President Trump announced the US would withdraw from in 2017. As part of the pact, Biden has committed the US to cutting greenhouse gases in half by 2030. However, it is below the commitments made by the European Union and the United Kingdom. For Biden to achieve any of his climate goals, it will be up to whether a divided Congress can pass his multi-trillion-dollar infrastructure bill that is making its way through the Capitol. The plan will see investment in electric vehicles and clean-energy technology.

The first weeks of Biden's presidency were focused on an economy that was in danger of collapsing due to the coronavirus pandemic. With unemployment and jobless claims at record highs, he was able to push through ‚Äî without Republican support ‚Äî the trillion-dollar rescue plan, which sent $1,400 (‚Ç¨1,150) checks to the pockets of each American household. Due to the vaccination rollout and the implementation of the American Rescue Plan, the job market added nearly 1 million jobs in March, bringing down the unemployment rate to 6%. Last April, the unemployment rate was hovering around 14%. Still, the employment numbers are still below pre-pandemic numbers and there are concerns about inflation rising as a result of the rescue plan, and the American people are likely to start holding the president accountable going forward.

snippet.description:
The world is far from having the number of COVID-19 vaccines needed to vaccinate every single person. Now, over 100 nations are pressing for a temporary patent waiver at the World Trade Organization to help speed up production. Some have suggested pharmaceutical companies are prioritizing profits over lives. Supporters of the waiver demand that know-how and technology be shared more widely - because the pandemic, they say, is an extraordinary, emergency situation. But a string of wealthy countries are opposing the waiver. And some say even if one was put in place, it would not increase vaccine production.

China has launched the core module of its first permanent space station. A rocket carrying the module blasted into space in the first of 11 missions needed to complete and crew the station by the end of next year. When finished, it will rival the only other space station circling our planet - the International Space Station or ISS.

snippet.description:
Mexico has the world's third-highest COVID-19 death toll, behind the United States and Brazil. Over 215,000 people are known to have died. Testing is limited and experts believe the real death toll is actually much higher. So the government is seeking to speed up vaccinations. Only around five percent of the population is fully inoculated and Mexico is appealing for more shots from abroad. Earlier this month President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador received the Astra Zeneca shot.

But Mexico is also developing its own vaccine. If approved, it would be the second Latin American vaccine. The Cuban vaccine is now in the final stages of testing.The vaccine is named "Patria," Spanish for 'homeland.' The company spearheading the drive is already eyeing clinical trials. The Mexican government hopes the vaccine can be approved for emergency use by the end of the year.

Authorities say it has several advantages, including that it can be administered in a nasal spray.The vaccine draws on US technology already used in other vaccines, which the Mexican developer says has proven safe and effective. The Mexican government has contributed to the funding.

President Lopez Obrador has condemned vaccine hoarding by rich countries in the past. He says his nation will share its vaccine with others.

President Lopez Obrador has condemned vaccine hoarding by rich countries in the past. He says his nation will share its vaccine with others.

snippet.description:
Joe Biden has pitched his proposals for what he calls a "once in a generation investment in America." In his first speech to Congress as US president, he outlined sweeping plans to increase wages and invest in infrastructure to create more jobs. He also stressed the need for the US to reassert its place in the world ‚Äì saying it must show its adversaries that "democracy still works."
Biden of course came into the presidency with lofty ambitions. He pledged to bring the country out of the pandemic, to fight racial injustice, and to make a 'once in a generation' investment - creating what he calls the strongest, most resilient and innovative economy in the world. 
100 days in to his presidency, he's poised to rack up quite a bill: 6 trillion dollars. That's the total cost of Biden's spending proposals so far this year. 
The first $1.9 trillion has already begun flowing into the economy, including $1,400 stimulus checks for many Americans. 
He's also proposed a $2.3 trillion infrastructure bill. It aims to update America's ailing roads and bridges, while also improving internet and electric vehicle networks. 
And then that $1.8 trillion bill aiming to improve child care and access to education. 
Biden plans to pay for this by raising taxes. He wants to increase the corporate tax rate to 28% and the top tax rate for America's wealthiest to 39.6%.
Biden spent decades in the US Congress as a senator. Now, he was back with an ambitious program that could see him becoming a transformational US president. 
He began by drawing attention to the historic fact that for the first time ever, the two people behind him, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Vice-President Kamala Harris, were women. Then, a grim summary of his first hundred days, combined with a note of optimism. 
Offering a wide-ranging vision of jobs, prosperity, and a new era of big government, with big spending plans, Biden said he would pay for it all with higher taxes on corporations and the super-rich. 
On international policy, Biden focused on adversaries Russia and China, linking the United States' ability to counter them to the success of his domestic policy agenda.
The circumstances of Biden's speech were unlike any previous presidential address. Members of Congress wore masks and were seated apart because of pandemic restrictions.

snippet.description:
After 16 years in power, Angela Merkel is nearing the end of her final term as chancellor. Germany is struggling to get the pandemic under control. A senior member of her party tells DW the country will be in good hands. Sarah Kelly asked CDU Member of the Bundestag J√ºrgen Hardt, about the conservatives' very public contest to pick a candidate to replace Merkel as chancellor, the government's mismanagement of the coronavirus response, and if German politicians will ever stand up to Russia or China.

snippet.description:
India's hospitals turn sick away as daily COVID cases approach 380,000 | DW News
India has set another global record in coronavirus cases, reporting almost 380,000 new infections in the last day. Medical aid from abroad has started arriving in the country, but hospitals are still struggling with shortages of staff and supplies, including oxygen.  India's health care system is so overwhelmed that many patients are being turned away.
A COVID-19 ward in a hospital in Delhi. The hospital, like so many, is full to overflowing. Medical staff are stretched to the limit, some falling ill with the disease themselves. Just one reality in India's coronavirus emergency. 
A woman receives oxygen outside a Sikh temple. She's not alone. There's no room for these people in Delhi's emergency wards. Relatives are left to cope with severely ill patients by themselves. 
A long line outside a Delhi gas supplier. People doing what they can to save their loved ones. Some get the oxygen they need. But there isn't enough to go round. 
The state of Delhi is reporting one death from COVID-19 every four minutes. And as the hospitals can't cope with the growing numbers of patients so the cremation grounds are struggling to cope with the rising numbers of deaths. The funeral pyres are burning day and night.
Delhi is one hotspot of India's COVID-19 emergency. Maharashtra state and the city of Mumbai is another. Here vaccination centers ran out of supplies on Wednesday. India is one of the biggest producers of vaccines. But it doesn't have enough to vaccinate the next 600 million people who will become eligible for the jab. 
Amid the frustration and suffering this: A 105-year-old man and his 95-year-old wife have survived a COVID-19 infection. The family says they want that story to give hope to others. For many fighting the disease, hope and prayers are all they have to help them.

snippet.description:
It's been a busy 100 days! Since Jan. 20, we've landed our Perseverance rover on Mars, and  flown our Ingenuity helicopter, a technology demonstration that caught a ride with the rover to the Red Planet. A ceremony marked the naming of our Mary W. Jackson Headquarters in Washington after the agency's first Black female engineer, honoring her contributions to our mission of exploration. Vice President Harris spoke with NASA astronauts on the International Space Station. Our Artemis program to return astronauts to the Moon completed a successful Green Run hot fire test for our Space Launch System rocket core stage, which arrived this week at Kennedy Space Center. NASA's SpaceX Crew-2 mission launched four astronauts to the space station, and we selected SpaceX as partner to build landers for Artemis missions. We made addressing climate change a priority, and celebrated Earth Day on and off the planet.

Read more: https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/biden-harris-administration-shows-strong-support-for-nasa-in-first-100-days

Producer: Lacey Young
Editors: Lacey Young, Sonnet Apple
Music: Universal Production Music

Our Artemis program to return astronauts to the Moon completed a successful Green Run hot fire test for our Space Launch System rocket core stage, which arrived this week at Kennedy Space Center. NASA's SpaceX Crew-2 mission launched four astronauts to the space station, and we selected SpaceX as partner to build landers for Artemis missions. snippet.description:
Delhi Capitals defeated Kolkata Knight Riders by seven wickets in Indian Premier League 2021 math no. 25 at Narendra Modi cricket stadium in Ahmedabad. Asked to bat first, Kolkata Knight Riders posted 154 for 6 in 20 overs. Opener Shubman Gill top-scored with a 38-ball 43 but KKR slipped to 82 for five before Andre Russell smashed 45 off 27 balls to take them past the 150-mark. The spin duo of Axar Patel and Lalit Yadav snared two wickets each for DC. In reply, Delhi Capitals chased down the target in 16.3 overs. Opener Prithvi Shaw blazed away to 82 off only 41 balls while sharing 132-run opening stand with Shikhar Dhawan.

snippet.description:
Special cargo from UAE with Covid-19 supplies arrived in India on Thursday. The cargo had 157 ventilators, 480 BiPAPs, and other medical supplies. This comes as many countries have come forward for India‚Äôs help. IAF has so far lifted 18 cryogenic oxygen containers from Dubai airport. More medical supplies from USA are scheduled to arrive on April 30.

snippet.description:
Exit polls on Thursday forecast a tight contest between the incumbent Trinamool Congress and the BJP in the high-profile West Bengal assembly polls and put the saffron combine ahead in Assam, while projecting a win for the ruling Left alliance in Kerala and for the DMK-led opposition in Tamil Nadu. The exit poll numbers were largely a setback for the Congress, which while falling short in Assam and Kerala may also lose its government in the union territory of Puducherry to the opposition alliance of AINRC-BJP-AIADMK. Exit polls were, however, divided in their forecast for the West Bengal polls, where the BJP ran a high-octane campaign in its bid to capture power in the state for the first time by ending Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee's 10-year old reign. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description:
From BMC stopping vaccination for three days to Bharat Biotech cutting its vaccine price, here are the top updates on coronavirus. BMC said that vaccination in Mumbai will be stopped for three days due to inadequate vaccine stock. This comes ahead of the third phase of vaccination, scheduled to start from May 1. Meanwhile, Bharat Biotech reduced its vaccine‚Äôs price to Rs 400 per dose for state governments from the earlier Rs 600 per dose. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description:
The US has said that it will be delivering COVID-19 relief materials worth over USD 100 million to India in the coming days, as the first flight carrying urgent health supplies left for the country. The flight took off from the Travis Air Force Base on the world's largest military aircraft on Wednesday night, the US Agency for International Development said. The shipment includes 440 oxygen cylinders and regulators, generously donated by the state of California, USAID said. In addition, on this first flight, USAID is sending 960,000 Rapid Diagnostic Tests to identify infections early to help prevent the community spread of COVID-19, and 100,000 N95 masks to protect India's frontline healthcare heroes, it added. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description:
Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday. The 69-year-old Congress leader made the announcement on Twitter. Gehlot isolated himself on Wednesday after his wife Sunita had tested positive. PM Narendra Modi wished good health and speedy recovery to Gehlot, his wife. Rajasthan Governor Kalraj Mishra also wished for Gehlot's speedy recovery. Meanwhile, former PM Manmohan Singh was discharged from AIIMS Delhi. The 88-year-old Congress veteran was hospitalised after testing positive for Covid. Singh was admitted to AIIMS trauma centre, a dedicated Covid facility, on April 19. Singh received the first dose of Covid vaccine on March 4 & second dose on April 3.

snippet.description:
Bharat Biotech on Thursday announced a cut in price of its COVID-19 vaccine 'Covaxin' it plans to sell to the states to Rs 400 per dose from the earlier Rs 600. This follows a widespread criticism of its pricing policy as it sold Covaxin to the central government at Rs 150 per dose. "Recognising the enormous challenges in the public healthcare system, we have made Covaxin available to state governments at a price of 400/ dose", Bharat Biotech said in its announcement. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description:
Like tens of millions of people, in 2017 Peter McCormack decided to get involved in Bitcoin -- the digital cryptocurrency that allows for direct, transparent financial transactions without a central bank. Unlike most people, he became a millionaire. Riding the highs of cryptocurrency trading, Peter began living a life of luxury, convinced he had figured out the secret of easy wealth. But just as soon as he had become a Bitcoin millionaire, he lost it all again. Now, armed with expert knowledge from his Bitcoin podcast, he's investing smarter and still all in one HODLing Bitcoin to the moon.

snippet.description:
Hunger has taken hold across Lebanon. Reeling from economic collapse, the coronavirus pandemic and skyrocketing inflation, millions of people are struggling to put food on the table this month, let alone commemorate Ramadan. For most, the usual festive sights, smells and sounds of the occasion have become distant memories.
 
According to the World Bank, half of Lebanon's six million people now live in poverty. Food prices have soared up to 400 percent, which the United Nations calls the highest food inflation in the world. 
 
The government has been unable to respond effectively since its prime minister resigned last year, following a massive port explosion in the capital.
 
Lebanon imports most of its food, but a cash crunch and the fallout of the blast have made it difficult to buy what people need. Unless the financial and political situation stabilises, the country could only have a couple months of supplies left, warn some supermarket traders. 

The situation has become so dire that the UN has added Lebanon to its list of countries at risk of "catastrophic famine," alongside Yemen, Afghanistan, Syria and other "hunger hotspots."
  
In this episode of The Stream we ask, can Lebanon be saved?

Join the conversation: 
TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream 
FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream 
Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe

snippet.description:
Somalia's president has backed down from extending his term by two years.

Mohamed Abdullahi Farmaajo has called for preparations to hold delayed elections.

But he and his opponents haven't been able to agree on how that vote should go ahead.

Rival factions have been fighting in the capital, Mogadishu, and Al Shabab is seizing the opportunity to extend its grip.

Could the political instability spark a new conflict?

Presenter: Mohammed Jamjoom

Guests:

Abdirahman Ibbi - Somali Member of Parliament.

Hodan Ali - Co-Founder, LeadNow.

Jihan Abdullahi Hassan - Former Director General of Somalia's Defence Ministry.

snippet.description:
Northern Ireland's First Minister Arlene Foster has announced she is resigning after calls within her party, the Democratic Unionist Party, for a leadership contest.
Critics blame Foster for the imposition of the Irish Sea border, a de facto customs border between Britain and Northern Ireland, which was agreed as part of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union. 
And in recent months, Northern Ireland has been hit by rioting, partly attributed to unionist concerns about the province's position in the UK being weakened. 
Many DUP members have been angry that Foster has not denounced the Northern Ireland protocol - which imposes checks on goods coming from Britain - more forcefully. 
The fallout from Brexit is likely to be one of the toughest challenges for her successor, too. 
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Nadim Baba reports.

snippet.description:
Coronavirus cases and deaths across India have reached a new high, as the country grapples with a devastating second wave.
More than 3,600 deaths and nearly 380,000 cases were reported on Thursday.
Despite all this, millions of people turned out to vote for regional elections in West Bengal, sparking fears the state may become the new epicentre.
Al Jazeera's Elizabeth Puranam reports from New Delhi.

snippet.description:
Healthcare experts in Nepal are warning the capital Kathmandu could see scenes similar to neighbouring India.
Infections are rising and hospital beds are filling up.
With new restrictions being imposed, officials say the situation is under control. 
But many residents aren't taking any chances.
Al Jazeera's Ramyata Limbu reports.

snippet.description:
Greece is shutting down what aid groups have hailed as an exemplary refugee camp on the island of Lesbos. 
Authorities are moving its residents to a new camp that can accommodate more than 3,000 people. 
But as Al Jazeera's John Psaropoulos reports, it is already gaining a reputation for poor living conditions.

snippet.description:
It's a day of grim milestones in India. Coronavirus infections in India have spiralled to more than 360,000 new cases in the past day - a global record. And it's led to more than 3,300 recorded deaths. 
That takes India's death toll past 200,000. 
However, many critics say the official numbers for both deaths and infections are far below the reality. 
Al Jazeera's Elizabeth Puranam has this report from New Delhi.

snippet.description:
Coronavirus restrictions are being relaxed in the Netherlands. 
But the country is going through its worst wave of infections since the beginning of the pandemic.
And hospitals are warning they will soon have to refuse to treat the critically ill. 
Virologists and medical workers have called the decision to ease restrictions dangerous and irresponsible. But many in the Netherlands could not wait to return to some normalcy. 
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Step Vaessen reports from Utrecht, the Netherlands.

snippet.description:
US President Joe Biden has presented what he calls his 'blueprint to build America'.  
In a wide-ranging speech to Congress on the eve of his 100th day in office, he promised trillions of dollars in investment in jobs, infrastructure and education.
Al Jazeera's Kimberly Halkett takes a look at some of his earlier promises, and the progress he's made in making them a reality.

snippet.description:
The indigenous Tejas fighter has been cleared to carry the Python-5 short-range air-to-air missile The DRDO announced on Wednesday 
This announcement by the DRDO is believed to be the first acknowledgment of the integration of the Python-5 missile on an Indian Air Force fighter. Talk of the Python-5 being offered to the Indian Air Force had been going for several years
The Python-5 is the second air-to-air missile of Israeli origin that will be integrated on the Tejas fighter. The first was the Derby medium-range air-to-air missile. Both weapons are made by the Israeli defense company Rafael. While the Derby is a radar-guided weapon thought to have a range of over 50km, the Python-5 is an infra-red guided missile that 'homes in' on the heat signature of a target. The Python-5 is believed to have a range of at least 20km
According to the official of DRDO, Tejas added the 5th generation Python-5 air-to-air missile in its air-to-air weapons capability on Tuesday. Trials were also aimed to validate the enhanced capability of already integrated Derby beyond-visual-range AAM on Tejas, The official said, the test-firing at Goa completed a series of missile trials to validate the performance of the aircraft under extremely challenging scenarios.
the official said the Derby missile achieved a direct hit on a high-speed maneuvering aerial target, and the Python missiles also achieved 100 percent hits, thereby validating their complete capability. The trials met all their planned objective

Households have saved an extra $5.4 trillion over the past year, according to a report by Moody's Analytics. Spending on items like travel and¬†restaurants plummeted during the Covid-19 pandemic, while many people's incomes were maintained by government aid. As some economies begin to lift restrictions, will consumers spend their savings and what sort of effect could it have on the¬†global economy? How should governments react to the spending splurge? We discuss¬†the potential benefits and pitfalls with¬†Gilles Mo√´c, chief economist at Axa Group.

snippet.description:
Over the past year, as Covid-19 has severely limited our ability to interact with the world beyond our front door, livestreams have helped transport us to places we couldn‚Äôt visit, people we couldn‚Äôt see and events we couldn‚Äôt attend. In China, live streaming services command an audience of nearly 560 million, with streamers broadcasting to devoted followers who tune in every night. Successful live streamers can earn thousands of dollars each month in direct donations from fans, and those at the very top earn millions from brand sponsorships and major contracts.

In the short documentary above, we enter two agencies that scout promising newcomers and mold them into high-earning stars. But what‚Äôs it like working for a company that engineers every aspect of your life ‚Äî and then requires you to livestream it all day?

- by David Borenstein (https://www.david-borenstein.com/)

Read more: https://nyti.ms/3073OoA

snippet.description:
In Israel, at least 15 people were killed and over 100 have been injured in stampede at religions ceremony.¬†

Israel's Ministry of Health reported 111 new Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, raising the total number of cases in the country to 838,211.

The total recoveries in Israel rose to 830,193 after 108 newly recovered cases were added, while the number of active cases decreased to 1,659, lowest in over a year.

The number of people vaccinated against Covid-19 in Israel has surpassed 5.39 million, or 57.8 per cent of its total population, since the vaccination campaign began on December 20, 2020.

snippet.description:
Watch the video to know how a number of people gathered in one of the ceremonies in Bihar's Buxar. All of them flouted the Covid protocols. Even after so many cases and deaths due to Covid, why people are not scared of flouting Covid protocols?

People in the age group of 18 to 44 years will have to wait for one more week to get vaccinated in Bihar.

According to a statement issued by the Bihar state health society, as the state government is lacking adequate stock of corona vaccine, it has been decided to reschedule the date of the corona vaccination programme in Bihar.

snippet.description:
Amid a deteriorating Covid-19 situation, the national capital on Thursday recorded its highest ever single-day toll from the disease in 24 hours as 395 deaths were reported.

Civil Aviation Minister Hardeep Singh Puri on Thursday said that 600 oxygen concentrators from US have arrived at the Delhi airport.

A day after recording the highest ever 1,035 Covid fatalities, Maharashtra's deaths came down by nearly one-fourth though Mumbai's toll continued to rise, with an increase in fresh infections, health officials said on Thursday.

snippet.description:
Watch the video to know whether 'Fighter Didi' and her political strategies will bring victory for TMCor not.¬†

According to the exit poll, the incumbent Trinamool Congress, led by Mamata Banerjee, is likely to retain power for the third consecutive term amid a robust challenge from the BJP.¬†

The survey suggests that Left, which had ruled the state for more than three decades, is likely to be reduced to a marginal player, despite having a pre-poll alliance with country‚Äôs grand old party ‚Äì Congress.

Stay connected for more

snippet.title: 'Fighter Didi' and her political strategies will bring victory for TMC?

snippet.description:
ABP News along with C-Voter conducted an Exit Poll to gauge the mood of voters in West Bengal. As per the survey, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is expected to make significant inroads in Bengal with bagging as much as 39 per cent vote share. It is to be noted that the saffron party managed to secure mere 10 per cen vote share in 2016 Assembly polls.¬†

In a massive jolt, Congress+Left alliance is most likely to lose its grounds in West Bengal as projections suggest that it will manage to secure only 15 per cent vote share. In 2016 Assembly polls, Congress & Left had secured a gigantic 38 per cent vote share.

snippet.description:
All eyes are on West Bengal's election results of May 2, know the Exit Poll's predictions here in this video.¬†

According to the survey conducted by ABP News, Mamata Banerjee-led TMC is expected to get somewhere around 152 to 164 seats in the 294-member West Bengal Assembly.¬†

Meanwhile, the BJP , which currently has 3 seats in West Bengal, is likely to bag somewhere between 109 to 121 seats in the state. The Congress and Left alliance will manage to secure around 14 to 25 seats. In 2016 Assembly elections, Congress+Left had managed to bag 76 seats.

snippet.description:
Craftspeople revive and preserve traditions. Qazaq TV News

#Craftspeople #traditions #traditionsofKazakhstan #dombyra #dombyramaking #wood #horseharnesses #Almaty #Turkistan

Resident of Turkistan region Kurmanali Agadilov recreates ancient horse harnesses. 

Preservation and revival of national culture, values and traditions - this is what a woodmaster Medetbai Omarov is doing. He makes various items, including furniture and musical instruments. A two-string dombyra by a craftsman from the Zhambyl region is in popular demand. He makes it from three types of wood: oak, spruce and pine. That‚Äôs the secret to making the instrument sound particularly loud, he said. Omarov is respected among the dombyra players for such a good quality of the instruments he makes.

‚ÄúThe woodwork is very durable. If the wood is of high quality, then an item will last a long time, and if not, then it will quickly become useless. Making this musical instrument is not easy,  it is important to observe all the proportions as the sound depends on it,‚Äù noted Sultanai Niyetkabylov, a dombyra player.

Resident of Turkistan region Kurmanali Agadilov recreates ancient horse harnesses. According to a legend, the nomads had 30 types of them. A craftsman managed to recreate 23. For this he had to study archival materials. Recreating historical objects is a responsible job that requires accuracy, Agadilov assures. It takes him six months to make only one saddle. Like the ancient nomads, he retains all manual processing technology. As a result, it is hard to distinguish Agadilov‚Äôs works from museum exhibits. He plans to teach the craft to the younger generation, so that the ancestral traditions are not forgotten over time.

‚ÄúThere are only a maximum of five or six types of Kazakh harnesses in the national museum, as well as in the museums of Almaty and Turkistan, although there were much more. Kazakhs are the only nation to have used more than 30 types of horse harnesses. A horse means a lot to a Kazakh. We need to develop equestrian tourism and harness the horses with ancient Kazakh harnesses. Also, we need a special school that has all the facilities to teach children this kind of craft,‚Äù Agadilov said.
