snippet.description:
Reggie examines the impact that gun violence and police brutality continue to have on the citizens of Chicago.
Against the backdrop of unprecedented gun violence, Reggie Yates travels to Chicago to investigate gun crime in President Obama's adopted hometown. In the year of filming this documentary, there were 468 murders in 2015. With many of the victims being young African-American men, who was to blame?
Reggie hears first-hand the accusations of police brutality, but after attending the aftermath of a shooting and funeral of a young black man, he comes to realise an even bigger problem is that the majority of killings are perpetrated by young black men living in Chicago's poorest neighbourhoods.

From Reggie Yates USA LIFE AND DEATH IN CHICAGO

Twitter: https://twitter.com/realstoriesdocs
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/RealStoriesChannel
Instagram - @realstoriesdocs

Real Stories Tapes: True Crime is a brand new podcast hosted by Emmy-nominated TV host and true-crime obsessive Stephanie Bauer (Searching For...). It takes some of the most popular true-crime documentaries on your Real Stories channel and transforms them into riveting audio, meaning you can enjoy them wherever you listen to your podcasts. https://podfollow.com/real-stories-tapes-true-crime

With the development of renewable energy accelerating, the pipeline business increasingly finds itself against the ropes. The Biden administration dealt a death blow to Keystone XL, and the fate of similar projects remains uncertain. As fossil fuel dependency begins to wane, this multibillion dollar industry could soon go the way of the dinosaurs.

snippet.description:
President Joe Biden‚Äôs speech to a joint session of Congress made history before it even started, with two women on the dias, with Vice President Kamala Harris and Nancy Pelosi as the second- and third-in-line to the presidency. CNN‚Äôs Chris Cillizza talks through his hits and misses from Biden‚Äôs speech ‚Äî outlining which moments mattered most and why.

About me: 
I was named "best dressed" in 7th grade. That, along with being CNN's editor at large and author of the daily "Point" newsletter are my proudest achievements. Look for me here every Tuesday and Thursday to find out what‚Äôs really going down in politics.  

CREDITS

Producer: Paul Dwyer
The Point Editor: Leigh Munsil

snippet.description:
Nijeer Parks couldn't have committed the crime. That didn't stop police from arresting him based off of a false facial recognition match. Here's why the technology can often misidentify Black people, with serious consequences.

Produced by John General & Jon Sarlin
Supervising Producer: Bronte Lord
Production Assistant: Sofia Barrett

snippet.description:
#HarshVardhan‚Äã #COVIDVaccine‚Äã #Coronavirus
Union Health Minister Harsh Vardhan on 29 April asked people not to panic and said oxygen is being made available from many sources. ‚ÄúOxygen was available in adequate quantity earlier also and now it is being made available from many sources by mobilising it from industry and abroad and by making available storage tankers and cryogenic tankers." He also said the majority of patients can recover at home while being in touch with a doctor.
‚ÄúThose who need oxygen should get it but it's not right if someone thinks he/she needs oxygen, due to lack of knowledge. Don't run here and there in panic. Majority of patients can recover at home while being in touch with doctor. I am not saying this just as the health minister but also as a doctor,‚Äù he said.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#Modi #Facebook
Social media giant Facebook Thursday said it had temporarily blocked a hashtag calling for Prime Minister Narendra Modi‚Äôs resignation ‚Äúby mistake‚Äù and that it wasn‚Äôt done on government orders. The development comes amid reports that social media companies are being asked to remove posts that are critical of the government‚Äôs handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

snippet.description:
#Internationalsupport #covid19 #HarshVardhanShringla 
Foreign Secretary Shri Harsh Vardhan Shringla said India is receiving support from over 40 countries in its fight against the Covid pandemic.  He also said India is looking at getting around 550 oxygen generating plants, 4,000 oxygen concentrators, 10,000 oxygen cylinders and 17 oxygen cryogenic tankers from abroad.

snippet.description:
Indian Ambassador to US Taranjit Singh Sandhu said the help from the
US during the 2nd wave of Covid reflects a strong partnership between the two countries. ‚ÄúOn 26 April, President Joe Biden spoke to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and expressed solidarity. President Biden reaffirmed that US is determined to support India's efforts to contain the Covid pandemic,‚Äù Sandhu said. He further said that this reflects a strong partnership between the two countries.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

snippet.description:
Federal MP Andrew Laming has created a headache for the Morrison Government in recent weeks with his alleged online bullying of two female constituents and photographing a young woman bending over at work. Dr Laming said the purpose of the photo was to "show a challenging work situation".

The controversial member for the Brisbane seat of Bowman apologised for any distress his communication caused, and on the advice of the Prime Minister, took medical leave to seek empathy training.

7.30 can reveal new claims by women alleging inappropriate behaviour. Dr Laming rejects these claims and says the exchanges were all routine and appropriate.

Statement from Andrew Laming - https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20693381-statement-from-andrew-laming

Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-04-29/women-say-andrew-lamings-behaviour-made-them-feel-uncomfortable/100086994

snippet.description:
Momentum to legalise euthanasia is gathering pace across Australia.

Victoria first introduced voluntary assisted dying laws nearly two years ago, and Western Australia and Tasmania will soon follow. Queensland's Government has promised a vote on the topic before the next election, and there's also legislation before the South Australian parliament.

In South Australia, one family is pushing for change based on their own painful personal experience.

Gabriella Marchant reports.

WARNING: This story explicitly discusses suicide. 

If this story has raised any issues for you, you can call Lifeline on 13 11 14, or Beyond Blue on 1300 22 46 36.

Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-04-29/rhys-habermann-and-voluntary-euthanasia/100062384

snippet.description:
A U.S. Air Force C-5 cargo aircraft left northern California on Wednesday carrying COVID-19 relief supplies for India. 

Crews at Travis Air Force Base, about 54 miles northeast of San Francisco, prepared cargo pallets containing oxygen cylinders, medical masks and other supplies for the airlift operation supported by the U.S. Department of Defense and U.S. Agency for International Development, according to a U.S. Department of Defense statement. 

The aircraft carried more than 400 oxygen cylinders and regulators, 1 million N-95 masks, and 1 million COVID-19 rapid diagnostic kits, according to the statement. 

With 379,257 new infections, India now has reported more than 18.3 million cases, second only to the United States. The Health Ministry also reported 3,645 deaths in the last 24 hours, bringing the total to 204,832. Experts believe both figures are an undercount, but it‚Äôs unclear by how much. 

(AP)

snippet.description:
In an article published by Real Clear Defense, Turkey‚Äôs top defense official Hulisi Akar argues that the mass killing and deportation of ethnic Armenians in the early 20th century Ottoman Empire was not an act of genocide. 

Akar‚Äôs article was posted on April 21, three days before Armenian Remembrance Day was marked on April 24 and before Joe Biden became the first U.S. president to use the phrase ‚ÄúArmenian genocide‚Äù in an official statement. 

‚ÄúEach year on this day, we remember the lives of all those who died in the Ottoman-era Armenian genocide and recommit ourselves to preventing such an atrocity from ever again occurring,‚Äù Biden said. 

According to Reuters, Biden told the Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on April 23, that he ‚Äúintends to recognize‚Äù the massacres of Ottoman Armenians as genocide in his Remembrance Day statement. 

Turkey, officially a U.S. ally and member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, does not recognize the Armenian genocide, and Erdogan responded in a nationally broadcast TV speech on April 26, that Biden had taken a ‚Äúwrong step,‚Äù and that his comments were ‚Äúgroundless and unfair.‚Äù 

In the past, Erdogan has denounced the accusation of genocide during World War I as ‚Äúslander‚Äù against his country. 

LINK: https://www.polygraph.info/a/fact-check-turkey-armenian-genocide/31225665.html

Reports of police violence and racial injustice resonate especially strongly in France, with its large population of ethnic Africans and Arabs. Yet cautious optimism by some in the United States and elsewhere that the guilty verdict in American former police officer Derek Chauvin‚Äôs murder trial might trigger societal change is less shared in France. From the Paris suburb of Bobigny, Lisa Bryant reports for VOA.¬†¬†¬†

Camera:¬†¬† Lisa Bryant, Agencies

snippet.description:
An Indian man who tested positive for the coronavirus got married in full PPE with permission from the government, Monday, April 26, as India grapples with a massive coronavirus surge. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî 
READ MORE: India set new records again Thursday in COVID-19 deaths and infections as its new vaccination registration program stumbled while millions of voters nonetheless turned out for an election in the state of West Bengal. 

Under the weight of a disastrous second surge of the disease, India‚Äôs efforts to begin registering its 1.4 billion people for inoculations didn‚Äôt go well Wednesday when the government launched a website for all Indians 18 and older to sign up for a vaccination drive that is set to begin Saturday. 

Many people flooded social media with complaints, however, that either the website had crashed or they were unable to make an appointment. 

The problems with the website come as the health ministry reported a record 379,257 new COVID-19 cases Thursday, including 3,645 fatalities, marking yet another one-day record for fatalities. The new figures have pushed India‚Äôs coronavirus casualty numbers well past 18.3 million total confirmed cases and 204,832 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî 
LINK: https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/india-struggles-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-amid-new-infection-death-rates

snippet.description:
The Greek-Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem performed the traditional ‚Äúwashing of the feet‚Äù ceremony outside the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Thursday, April 29. 

It is performed on the last Thursday before Orthodox Easter to kick off a three-day commemoration. 

The ceremony is in tribute to Jesus washing the feet of his disciples at the Last Supper. (AP)

snippet.description:
President Joe Biden is heading to Georgia Thursday, the day after his first nationally televised address to Congress. 

READ MORE: ‚ÄúAfter 100 days of rescue and renewal, America is ready for takeoff,‚Äù U.S. President Joe Biden told a joint session of Congress, using the occasion to push his proposed $4 trillion in government spending and tout his overall performance in coping with a series of historic crises since taking office in January.   

The president, in an address on Wednesday night, said he had inherited a nation in crisis facing the worst pandemic in a century, the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, and ‚Äúthe worst attack on our democracy since the Civil War.‚Äù   

The address on the eve of his 100th day in office, was not deemed a ‚ÄúState of the Union‚Äù presentation because it was delivered in the first year of a new president‚Äôs term. It was also shorn of some of the typical pomp of the annual presidential speech to both the House and Senate because of coronavirus restrictions.   

Typically, as many as 1,600 people pack the House chamber to attend a presidential speech. Only 200 people, mostly members of Congress‚Äîjoined by a small number of officials from other government branches, plus select family members‚Äîattended. They were socially distanced in the House chamber and wore masks. 

LINK: https://www.voanews.com/usa/america-ready-takeoff-biden-tells-congress

snippet.description:
The political and economic crisis in Lebanon started long before the devastating explosion on August 4, 2020. But since then, the country has been in freefall. Young people in particular are asking whether they have a future there at all.

For months, the Lebanese people have been calling for regime change. The government resigned at the end of 2019 after months of sometimes violent protests, but the economic situation is still deteriorating. The Lebanese currency is in freefall, the price of food is rocketing and to make matters worse, the number of coronavirus infections is rising dramatically. The people saw the explosion in Beirut‚Äôs port area on August 4 as another symbol of political failure. More than 170 people were killed and around 6,000 people injured, and an estimated $15 billion worth of damage done. Documents show that the authorities were aware of the improper storage of the highly explosive ammonium nitrate, which is why Nour Bassam and her fianc√© Hussein Achi are not giving up. The young couple have been fighting for political change since last fall. Immediately after the explosion, Hussein and his organization, "Min Tishreen‚Äù set up an emergency aid center in the ruins of the Mar Michael district. But Hussein is concerned with more than distributing food and medicines and rebuilding the destroyed city. While many of his friends are deserting their country, he wants to establish a new political culture in his homeland. Hussein senses the people‚Äôs anger at the country's old political elite. Will they succeed in asserting themselves against their corrupt rulers?"

[This documentary has been reuploaded due to technical issues. The video was originally uploaded in November 2020.]

snippet.description:
#Karnataka #Bengaluru #COVID19 #RepublicTV 

Karnataka Health Minister K Sudhakar claimed that 20-25% of COVID patients in the state were untraceable as they switched off their phones soon after their tests returned positive. Speaking to reporters, K Sudhakar informed that patients who had tested positive for COVID were avoiding tracing by making their phone unreachable or by switching off the device, and noted that such patients will be listed under a new category titled 'non-traceable cases' in the daily health bulletin. The state Health Minister further informed that such cases would be handed over to the police and noted that there was approximately 20-25% of such cases in the state. 

"We are unable to reach several people as phones are switched off or have been made not reachable. We finally put them in a category called as non traceable contacts. These cases will be handed over to cops. Such people amount to about 20-25% of the people", Karnataka Health Minister K Sudhakar said. 

Earlier on Wednesday, Karnataka Revenue minister R Ashoka had opined that 'at least 2000-3000' COVID patients from Bengaluru were untraceable as they had switched off their phones and left their homes. Ashoka noted that such cases led to further spread of COVID and said that the non-traceable patients only turned on their phones when they were critical and were looking for beds in Bengaluru. The Karnataka Minister appealed to the patients testing positive for COVID to keep their phones turned on and urged them to take the free medicines given by the government, citing that the situation could be controlled then and there if done so.

snippet.description:
#OrderOfTheRisingSun #Japan #India #RepublicTV 

Prime Minister Narendra Modi's former Principal Secretary and Trustee of the Ram Temple Trust Nripendra Mishra has been awarded Japan's National honour the 'Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star' by the Japanese government. Misra was awarded for his role and contribution to furthering India-Japan bilateral relations.

It is a Japanese award that was established on 10 April 1875 by Emperor Meiji. The badge features rays of sunlight from the rising sun. It is the third-highest order honour by the Japanese government. The order is awarded to those who have made distinguished achievements in international relations, promotion of Japanese culture, advancements in their field, development in welfare or preservation of the environment.

Ambassador of Japan to India Satoshi Suzuki took to Twitter and congratulated Nripendra Misra.

Nripendra Misra is a retired 1967 batch IAS officer from the Uttar Pradesh cadre. He had served as Principal Secretary to the Prime Minister of India, Narendra Modi from 2014 to 2019. He has also served as the chairperson of the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India. Misra has served in various positions for both the Government of India as well as for the Government of Uttar Pradesh. In the year 2020, he was appointed as the head of the temple construction committee of the Shri Ram Janmabhoomi Tirth Kshetra Trust. PM Modi had described Misra as "among the most outstanding officers who have a great grasp of public policy and administration" and an associate who had taught him a lot when he was new to Delhi in 2014 and said his "guidance remains extremely valuable."

PM Modi had described Misra as "among the most outstanding officers who have a great grasp of public policy and administration" and an associate who had taught him a lot when he was new to Delhi in 2014 and said his "guidance remains extremely valuable."

snippet.description:
#AkaliDalChiefBooked #COVID19 #Punjab #RepublicTV 

Chandigarh, Apr 29 (PTI) SAD chief Sukhbir Singh Badal along with several other activists of the party's youth wing have been booked for allegedly flouting COVID-19 guidelines by holding a gathering at Punjab's Muktsar district, police said on Thursday.

Several activists of the Students Organization of India, a youth wing of the Shiromani Akali Dal on Wednesday had held a gathering at the residence of Badal in Muktsar.

Arshdeep Singh Robin Brar, who was newly appointed as president of SOI, along with other activists of the outfit went to meet Badal. The SAD chief even addressed the gathering of more than 100 people.

Police registered a case against four people by name, including Sukhbir Badal and Arshdeep Singh Robin Brar, and 100-150 unidentified ones under IPC section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), said SHO of Lambi police station Chander Shekhar.  The Punjab government has imposed a ban on all social, political and cultural gatherings in the wake of a resurgence in COVID-19 infection in the state. PTI CHS VSD NSD NSD

snippet.description:
The India Today-Axis My India exit poll has predicted that the Pinarayi Vijayan-led Left Democratic Front (LDF) is likely to win around 104-120 seats out of the total 140 seats in the Kerala Assembly election.
While Congress-led United Democratic Front (UDF) is expected to bag 20-36 seats and National Democratic Alliance (NDA) may get 0-2 seats.
For the Kerala exit poll the survey was conducted across 140 constituencies with a sample size of 28,124.
#IndiaTodayExitPolls #ExitPolls2021 #KeralaExitPoll

snippet.description:
Natalia Kaliada and Nikolai Khalezin run the Belarus Free Theatre in Minsk, Belarus, which puts on dissident productions critical of the regime of Alexander Lukashenko ‚Äî referred to by many as the last dictator in Europe. 

A decade ago, facing political persecution, Natalia and Nikolai fled to an undisclosed location in the UK where they now live in exile. Their work in Minsk has never stopped, despite frequent arrests of their actors and crew. 

After widespread protests rocked Belarus in August 2020, the threats against the couple have only increased, with a state-controlled paper vowing that they‚Äôd be hung ‚Äúside by side.‚Äù

Crime and COVID are on the rise in the suburb of Southall in London that‚Äôs home to the largest Punjabi community outside of India. 

At various times during the pandemic, it has recorded some of the highest COVID rates in the United Kingdom. VICE World News reveals how deep-rooted cultural beliefs and government distrust are fueling crime and vaccine hesitancy.
